awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Stagnant Flood Water Quality Improvement: Role of Sediment and Interactions between Effective Microorganisms and Indigenous Microorganisms
awd_abstract_narration:
1219755/Khan

Thailand is experiencing the worst flood in the history of the country. The flood water has affected more than two million people in Bangkok. Due to poor drainage, the flood water is stagnant in most areas leading to water quality issues.  Odor emission and waterborne pathogen proliferation are potential problems. The Thai Government is suggesting the use of effective microorganisms (EMs) to alleviate the problems. EMs are available in both liquid and solid forms consisting of three microbial groups including lactic acid bacteria, yeast, and photosynthetic bacteria.  A hypothesis is that EMs would overtake indigenous microorganisms that are pathogens.  The overarching goals of this project are to investigate type and quantity of sediment and to study microbial community within the sediment. The microbial community investigation will focus on: 1) Indigenous microorganisms including sulfate reducing bacteria that are responsible for odor production and known waterborne pathogens such as Vibrio chlorella, Salmonella typhi, Escherichia coli, and Cryptosporidium and 2) Microbial groups associated with EMs.  The central hypotheses are that the presence of sediment with high organic contents is associated with odor, and sediment harbors sulfate reducing bacteria and pathogens but not microbial groups associated with EMs. The PIs will test these hypotheses: 1) Determine the type and quantity of sediment in different areas (with and without odor and with and without EM application) and 2) Determine the microbial community and its diversity in the sediment. 

Intellectual Merit
The proposed research will benefit practical applications on flood water quality management via sediment control. The use of EMs for controlling sulfur reducing bacteria and waterborne pathogens is potentially transformative.  Results from this research could be applicable across different fields as EMs have been used in agronomy, food science, and health sciences. The project is interdisciplinary in nature requiring integrated knowledge in environmental engineering, molecular microbiology, and hydrology.

Broader Impacts
This project meets the RAPID funding criteria because of the need to collect sediment samples after the flood water is drained; the drainage is projected to happen early in 2012.  The proposed research will have an impact on the well-being of flood victims. Flooding is one of the major natural disasters and occurs throughout the world. The information gained through the project could be useful to post flood cleanup workers in term of reducing risk in contacting with pathogenic microorganisms. Research findings can be applied to the southern states of the U.S. because of similarities in climate and long periods of flood water inundation.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Flood events can be short or long. For long flood events, inundated water can remain from a few weeks to several months and tends to be stagnant. The stagnant flood water condition, which is common throughout the world including the United States, sometimes leads to sediment accumulation. Two major concerns associated with the stagnant flood water conditions are odor and pathogens. One of the common practices to address these two concerns is an addition of effective microorganisms (EMs), which come in different forms including liquid, powder, and solid, to the stagnant flood water. It is believed that EMs can proliferate and dominate the microbial ecology of the flood water and sediment and in turn suppress odor causing and pathogenic microorganisms. The project dealt with two major research questions related to stagnant flood events. Can EMs solve odor and pathogen problems associated with stagnant flood water and sediment? Does stagnant flood sediment harbor pathogenic microorganisms? Using a major stagnant flood water event in Thailand in 2011-2012 that affected 12 million people as a test bed, these questions were answered by characterizing the water and sediment samples for physical, chemical, and microbiological quality. The project involved the use of a powerful genomic approach called metagenomic for elucidating microbial communities in the flood water and sediment with and without EM applications.

The project yielded several key findings. Microbial communities in the flood water and sediment were very diverse with the sediment having slightly higher diversity than the water. The communities were not dominated by certain groups of microorganisms. The higher diversity was observed even within groups of microorganism including bacteria, fungi, and yeast. Several types of microorganisms were found in both the water and sediment. EMs had no effect on microbial communities and in turn physical (including color and odor), chemical, and microbiological quality of the water and sediment. Two out of three microbial groups that are the main compositions of EMs were found in both the sediment and water regardless of the EM application. None of the concerned microbial pathogens were found in the sediment. However, a pathogenic protozoan, Cryptosporidium, was detected in three out of twenty water samples. This pathogen has caused several waterborne outbreaks throughout the world including one in Milwaukee, Wisconsin in 1993 that affected 400,300 people and caused 104 deaths. The species of the protozoan detected is associated with cattle. The key ultimate project outcomes are revelations that EMs are not effective tools for abatements of odor and pathogens and the stagnant flood sediment does not harbor common waterborne pathogens. The fact that a pathogen was found in multiple water samples is a public health concern. For human resource and networking developments, the project helped in producing a female Ph.D. graduate and initiating an international research collaboration which has benefited both Thailand and the United States.


Last Modified: 03/30/2014
Modified by: Eakalak Khan
